ComicInfo.Title: 1979; My name is Killer; 12th Street and Vine; Anima; 1979; Since I Don't Have You
ComicInfo.Summary:
This is volume four in the series. Uses the same oversize magazine format as volume one.
Vol. 1- 1982-1996 (50 issues in magazine format) Vol. 2- 2001-2007 (20 issues in standard US comic book periodical format) Vol. 3- 2008-2016 (8 issues as Love and Rockets: New Stories in trade paperback format)
Comes with at least one cover variant per issue available exclusively from the publisher. Each variant has its own individual front & back cover.US comic book store release date 2017-12-06.1979: Malo, this time dressed up in "punk" gear, tries to convince Hopey to smuggle drugs across the Mexican border for him.
My name is Killer: Killer tries to come to terms with the less than rapturous response to her newly started singing career.
12th Street and Vine: Maggie finally lets Ray know that it was her brother Calvin who brutally assaulted him. A story told from Ray's point of view, first person perspective.
Anima: The Emperor of Blotos is arrested and condemned to banishment in the Asteroid of Sorrows for unleashing the Hellmets. However, just as his judgement is given, a Hellmet arrives and incinerates his prosecutors after taking over his body. Newly super-powered Isla and her sister Lumina look for a spaceport to get to their home planet, but the Hellmet that Anima had defeated arrives to try to take over Isla's body again.
1979: In Del Chimney's house, Del tries to prevent Doyle from starting a fight, Maggie waits for Hopey, who arrives with Hilary Pute's soon-to-be destroyed lunchbox. Del nixes Malo enlisting Maggie in his scheme to smuggle drugs over the Mexican border.
Since I Don't Have You: Pipo finds out Soledad Marquez has died, then visits her now-officially divorced ex Fritz before taking a flight to Palomar. In a flashback to the time period of the earliest Palomar story, fourteen-year-old Pipo deals with fluctuating interest from Manuel and persistent attention from Soledad. In a teenage pique, she tells Soledad to scare Manuel with an unloaded gun but he winds up killing him. Flash-forward to the mid-to-late nineties post-Palomar period, the now adult and well-off Pipo reconciles with the still-imprisoned Soledad.
